Topic: Biotechnology, Bioethics and Ethnography.


This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement:- Theme. 
Where and how does life begin? How does Catholicism understand IVF or Judaism understand human cloning? Who are the parents of children born from egg or sperm donation under different forms of Islam in different parts of the world? How should a modern, religiously pluralistic society address controversial bioethical issues related to abortion? Why are "sacred bioethics" a necessary ingredient in today's bioethics debates? This course introduces students simultaneously to methods in the anthropology of religion and medical anthropology and cross-cultural bioethics. No prerequisites but students should come prepared to read, discuss and learn! This course is meant for students interested in human health and biology as well as humanities and social sciences.


(Same as  ANT 385 4 & JS 370 1)
course_description: Designed to explore the mind/body connection as a paradigm to understand religion and healing. Will examine the role of faith, ritual, prayer, and meditation in various models of healing.
